oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Comparison of fan type and effect on dairy cow temperatures on a California dairy during summer conditions
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Smith, Scott T.
Jardon, Phillip W.
Dhuyvetter, KevinC.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: heat stress
fan
reproductive performance
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Heat stress in dairy cattle is an economically important factor on dairy farms. Annual economic losses due to heat stress on US dairies have been estimated at $1.2 billion (Key, 2014). Reproductive performance, especially pregnancies per AI, has been shown to be negatively impacted at body temperatures above 39.1Â° C (Periera 2013). Multiple factors affect cow cooling effectiveness, including shade/housing type, soakers, and use of fans to aid in evaporative cooling. Fan type in a commercial setting has not been extensively evaluated as to effects on dairy cow heat abatement and was the objective of this study.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: American Association of Bovine Practitioners Conference Proceedings; 2021 Annual Conference Proceedings; 248
